title: 114_hr2013
content: The "Fitness Integrated Into Teaching Kids Act" or the "FIT Kids Act" amends the Carol M. White Physical Education Program to award grants for physical education programs for kindergarten through 12th-grade students. The purpose of this subpart is to award grants for physical education programs for kindergarten through 12th-grade students. Funds will be allocated to local educational agencies, community-based organizations, and states on a competitive basis. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to local educational agencies and community-based organizations for physical education programs for K-12 students. The programs may include fitness education, motor skills instruction, and cognitive development. The physical education program aims to enhance students' physical, mental, and social development through motor skills and activities. It also includes instruction in cognitive concepts, promotes healthy lifestyle habits, and fosters social skills. Professional development opportunities for teachers are provided to stay updated on research and trends. Extracurricular activities like team sports are not considered part of the program. The physical education program aims to improve students' physical, mental, and social development through motor skills and activities. Applications for grants under this program must include a plan to enhance physical education programs to meet State standards. Private school and home-schooled students can participate in funded activities. An annual report to the Secretary is required to continue receiving funding for multiyear grants. The administrator of a grant must submit an annual report to the Secretary to continue receiving funding for physical education programs. The report should describe activities conducted and show progress towards meeting State standards. Administrative expenses are limited to 5% of grant funds, and the Federal share of program costs is capped at 90% for the first year and 75% for subsequent years. The Secretary ensures equitable distribution of grants among educational agencies and organizations in urban and rural areas. A report to Congress is required within 2 years of the first grant award, detailing program success and making recommendations for program continuation and improvement. "SEC. 5505. Grants to states for equitable distribution among educational agencies in urban and rural areas. Report to Congress required within 2 years of first grant award." The Secretary is authorized to award grants to States for comprehensive programs addressing physical activity, education, fitness, and nutrition based on research and needs analysis. States must submit applications detailing needs and improvement plans. The State must submit a plan for improving physical activity, education, fitness, and nutrition of students, including developing a measurement system and ensuring data quality and coordination with other programs. The State's procedures for collecting data to implement a measurement system include coordinating activities with other programs, assisting local agencies in aligning activities with other funds, and soliciting and approving subgrant applications. This also involves considering analysis results for subgrant distribution and addressing diverse geographic needs. The State receiving a grant must reserve a small portion for administration and use the rest to award subgrants. They must establish a physical education requirement and implement a statewide measurement system. The State must develop and implement a statewide measurement system to measure the progress of local educational agencies. They must provide public reports on the data collected and award subgrants to eligible applicants based on the results of the measurement system. The State must establish a measurement system to track local educational agency progress, award subgrants to eligible applicants based on data collected, provide professional development for physical and health education teachers, and monitor subgrant implementation. The State must establish a measurement system to track local educational agency progress related to physical fitness, physical education, student health, and nutrition. This includes monitoring the amount of time students spend in physical education, adherence to national guidelines, teacher certification, and the presence of physical education programs in schools. The State must compile statistics on physical education teachers' certification, schools with health councils, and facilities used for physical education. Uniform definitions must be used for compiling these statistics. The State must compile statistics on physical education teachers' certification, schools with health councils, and facilities used for physical education, using uniform definitions and data collection procedures. Subgrants based on need will be awarded to eligible local applicants. The State awards subgrants to eligible local applicants based on need, size, and scope to promote physical activity, education, fitness, and nutrition. Priority is given to applications demonstrating the greatest need according to the State's measurement system. Applicants must submit an application to the State to receive a subgrant. Priority for subgrants is given to applications showing the greatest need based on the State's measurement system and serving schools with high poverty levels. Recipients must promote physical activity, education, fitness, and nutrition as part of a comprehensive strategy. The subgrants prioritize schools with high poverty levels based on the State's measurement system. Recipients must implement scientifically valid interventions and collect data for reporting to the State educational agency. Additionally, policies should be established to expand access to quality physical activity opportunities. The State must prioritize schools with high poverty levels for subgrants and implement valid interventions. Policies should expand access to quality physical activity opportunities, consider unique needs of students with disabilities and English learners, and submit annual reports on fund usage. Funds under this subpart must supplement, not replace, other Federal, State, or local funds for physical education activities.
